Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A researcher will conduct a study to investigate whether a new medicated skin cream is effective in curing a common skin ailment. The researcher will use one of the following designs for the study. Method <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">I</mtext></math>: Obtain <math alttext="320" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>320</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with the skin ailment. Randomly assign <math alttext="120" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use the medicated skin cream each day. Randomly assign <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after six months. Method <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">II</mtext></math>: Randomly select <math alttext="320" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>320</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people with the skin ailment to use the medicated skin cream each day. Observe the number of people cured after six months. (a) If the researcher were to choose Method <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

Randomly assign <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after six months. Method <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">II</mtext></math>: Randomly select <math alttext="320" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>320</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people with the skin ailment to use the medicated skin cream each day. Observe the number of people cured after six months. (a) If the researcher were to choose Method <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

(b) The researcher is considering using an alternate design: a matched-pairs design. Explain a benefit that a matched-pairs design would bring to the investigation and identify a characteristic that can be used to group the <math alttext="320" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>320</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people into pairs.

The researcher conducted the study using the design described in Method <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results of the study are shown in the following bar graph. (c) Suppose one person is randomly selected from each group (Medicated Skin Cream and Placebo) in the study. A student claims that the likelihood of selecting a person cured of the common skin ailment is less for the Medicated Skin Cream group than for the Placebo group because the total number cured in the study is less for the Medicated Skin Cream group than for the Placebo group. Explain the error in the student’s claim.

The researcher will use the sample data to complete a hypothesis test to investigate the following research question. Is there a difference between use of the new medicated skin cream and use of the placebo in the curing of the common skin ailment? Let <math alttext="p sub M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would be cured using the medicated skin cream, and let <math alttext="p sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would be cured using a placebo. The hypotheses of the test used by the researcher are as follows. <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub M equals p sub P. H sub a: p sub M is not equal to p sub P." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) Describe, in the context of the study, a consequence of making a Type <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error.

The conditions for inference have been met. A <math alttext="95%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval to estimate <math alttext="p sub M minus p sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.03 comma 0.24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>0.03</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>0.24</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based on the confidence interval, how should the researcher answer the research question? Explain your answer.
